Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Novel Nanomaterial-based Hybrid Scaffolds for Treatment of Cardiovascular Disease
Award.AbstractNarration:
As the leading cause of death, heart disease is responsible for 1 in every 4 deaths of Americans according to the statistics release by CDC in 2015. Therefore, in order to promote functional recovery from cardiovascular disease (CVD), there is strong value in generating a robust biomaterial for the restoration of lost cardiac tissue from heart failure or cardiac injury. Stem cells, on the other hand, hold the key to regenerative medicine due to their unique ability to both self-renew and differentiate into different types of adult cells. In partnership with Professor Yong Chen's Group at iCeMS, Kyoto University, the research conducted in this award has a strong impact in improving current stem cell therapy in an innovative way. This research award also carries the intellectual merit to be transformative in the applications of other stem cell therapy treatment for other degenerative disorders and diseases. A novel way to efficiently differentiate stem cells into a desired lineage, cardiomyocyte in this case, is sure to be beneficial to the society as it has the potential to make stem cell therapy more accessible to the patients in the future.

The proposed project seeks to gain understanding and further enhance the differentiation of cardiomyocyte from human pluripotent stem cells. To this end, we have recently developed a unique nanomaterial-nanofiber hybrid scaffold that combines the well-established properties of graphene-based nanomaterials with electrospun nanofibers in a single stem cell differentiation conduit. Nanomaterials are becoming popular for bioapplications due to the presence of a variety of chemical functionalities that are well-known to provide permissive surfaces for increasing biomolecule and cellular adsorption. Our graphene-nanofiber hybrid scaffolds have demonstrated previously to be not only biocompatible, but found to selectively guide the differentiation of neural stem cells into mature oligodendrocytes, without the introduction of exogenous factors into the cell culture media. Base on the foundation of this previous studies, and given the difficulties of generating a robust population of mature cardiomyocytes, our hybrid nanomaterial scaffold approach can serve as a powerful resource in the arsenal for improving cardiovascular disease treatment.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the leading cause of death, heart disease is responsible for one in every four deaths in the United States according to the statistics released by the CDC. During a heart attack, blood flow to the cardiac muscle cuts off, and cardiac muscle begins to die. As this irreversible damage progresses to the cardiomyocyte, a cascade of detrimental events can occur. Therefore, to promote functional recovery from cardiovascular disease (CVD), there is a strong clinical need for generating a robust biomaterial for the restoration of lost cardiac tissue from heart failure or cardiac injury given the intrinsically limited regenerative potential of the cardiomyocyte.

Stem cells, on the other hand, hold the key to regenerative medicine due to their unique ability to both self-renew and differentiate into different types of somatic cells. There have been studies involving transplanting bone derived stem cells, skeletal myoblasts, resident cardiac progenitor cells through endocardial injection, intracoronary injection, and open heart surgery to the injury site. However, the benefits of these approaches alone have shown to be very moderate. This 2016 EAPSI project sought to gain understanding and further enhance the differentiation of cardiomyocyte from human pluripotent stem cells.

To this end, we have recently developed a unique nanomaterial-nanofiber hybrid scaffold that combines the well-established properties of graphene-based nanomaterials with electrospun nanofibers in a single stem cell differentiation conduit. Nanomaterials are becoming popular for bio-applications due to the presence of a variety of chemical functionalities that are well-known to provide permissive surfaces for increasing biomolecule and cellular adsorption. Our graphene-nanofiber hybrid scaffolds have demonstrated previously to be not only biocompatible but found to selectively guide the differentiation of neural stem cells into mature oligodendrocytes, without the introduction of exogenous factors into the cell culture media. Base on the foundation of this previous studies, and given the difficulties of generating a robust population of mature cardiomyocytes, our hybrid nano-material scaffold approach can serve as a powerful resource in the arsenal for improving cardiovascular disease treatment.

As the birthplace of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs), Kyoto University is certainly an attractive environment for any researchers conducting of stem cell research. Through an international research collaboration with the scientists at a state of the art Japanese stem cell research institute, scientific exchanges of nuances in both techniques and understanding in the field of nanomaterials and stem cell biology took place. Most importantly, the close relationship of conducting researching in a foreign country helped to transfer knowledge and technology back to the United States. Currently, the established project is an ongoing international collaborative effort.

As the scientific community become global, the proposed work will help establish a strong international pivotal partnership between a Japanese and an American research group. Just like the tremendous impact iPSCs have on biology and medicine, a novel way to efficiently differentiate pluripotent stem cells into the desired lineage, cardiomyocyte, in this case, is sure to be beneficial to the society as it has the potential to make stem cell therapy more accessible to the patients in the future. The results obtained from this proposal will be published in high impact peer-reviewed journals such as Nature Nanotechnology, Advanced Materials, and ACS Nano. Additionally, data gathered will be used to apply for presentation at conferences held by Material Research Society and Gordon Research Conferences.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2017
Modified by: Sy-Tsong D Chueng
